topic.title: PHY <-> MAC <-> OTN Datapaths

li.p: 10GE (7a), 25GE (7b), 50GE (7c), 100GE (7d) Ethernet clients GFP mapped into OTN via Ethernet MACs.
10G (7e), 25G (7f), 50G (7g), 100G (7h), 200G (7i), 400G (7j) Ethernet clients IMP+BMP mapped into OTN via Ethernet MACs.

body.p: On the receive path, the different Ethernet clients (10GE, 25GE, 50GE, 100GE, 400GE) coming from the SERDES go through the PHY RX blocks that performs the PMA, FEC and PCS receive functions. The traffic then pass through the RX MAC that delineate Ethernet packets, deleting preamble, all idles and O/S. These packets are forwarded and stored into the ECPB packet buffer. The RX MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_I provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities.

On the transmit path, the MAPOTN subsystem demaps the GFP traffic and the packets stored into the ECPB packet buffer. These packets are then extracted toward the ENET subsystem. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_E provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The MAC adds the preamble, idles and OS. The PHY TX block performs the PMA, FEC and PCS transmit functions. The PHY rate information (normally nominal) is carried for each channel to the SERDES outside the ENET subsystem.
